awd_titl_txt: Nanomanufacturing and System Integration of Multi-Functional Metallic Pyramidal Probes
awd_abstract_narration:
Optical microscopy and spectroscopy is limited in resolution to roughly half the wavelength of light, generally about 200 to 250 nanometers. Scientists can overcome this limit using a sharp metal tip as an antenna to focus light into the optical near-field, gleaning crucial information about nanoscale light-matter interactions  inaccessible by other methods. Current state-of-the-art tips for near field applications are fabricated one at a time, are fragile, and have rough surfaces. These manufacturing inconsistencies limit resolution and often give irreproducible results. The objective of this project is to manufacture, integrate, characterize, and disseminate a new generation of metal probes. Dissemination of reproducible, high-performance, and multi-functional probes will democratize access to high-resolution near-field optical microscopy and spectroscopy and enable its use in user facilities, promoting this technology from the realm of a few experts to general use. 

The research team will use a high-throughput manufacturing technique known as template stripping for reproducible, wafer-scale production of nanometrically sharp, noble metal pyramidal tips. Crystalline-orientation-dependent wet etching of silicon will be used to define an atomically smooth template, into which gold or silver will be deposited. The metal will then be stripped off, using epoxy, exposing the ultra-smooth, sub-nanometer roughness, backside surface. The resulting ultrasmooth metal pyramids mitigate parasitic random hotspots, endemic to other metallization techniques, and promote optical energy delivery to and concentration at the tip. Robust packaging methods will be developed to integrate these probes with scanning probe microscopy systems. These scanning-probe-affixed metal pyramids will be quality controlled in an atomic force microscope, enhancing spectroscopic signals from standard samples while simultaneously acquiring topographic images. Detailed manufacturing and packaging protocols will be published in peer-reviewed journals and provided to researchers upon request. This will transform near-field microscopy and spectroscopy from a difficult niche technique used by a small number of specialists to a widespread, routine characterization method adopted by many researchers in broad range of disciplines such as nanotechnology, materials science, chemistry, and biology.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this project was to manufacture and characterize metallic pyramidal probes for near-field optical microscopy and spectroscopy applications. Near-field scanning optical microscopy (NSOM) and tip-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (TERS) provide crucial nanoscale information inaccessible by conventional far-field imaging methods. The widespread use of NSOM and TERS, however, is often limited by the poor reproducibility and quality of currently available near-field optical probes. The manufacture and dissemination of reproducible, high-performance, and multi-functional probes that integrate optical and electrical capabilities are highly desirable.

The intellectual merits of this project were to establish a new unconventional fabrication method called template stripping as a practical technique for nanomanufacturing of high-quality sharp metallic probes for the aforementioned applications. In this technique, a metal film is deposited in a precisely patterned crystalline silicon template then stripped off, exposing the ultra-smooth, sub-nanometer roughness, backside metallic surface. The PI’s team employed anisotropic wet etching of silicon wafers to mass-produce metallic pyramids with sub-10-nm-sharp tips and ultra-smooth facets. It is not trivial to produce such high-quality metallic pyramidal structures using other approaches such as direct etching or milling of noble metals. These scanning-probe-affixed gold or silver pyramids have been shown to concomitantly enhance fluorescence and Raman signals from underlying molecular samples while acquiring topographic images. The PI has also developed packaging methods to integrate these pyramidal probes with conductive wires for use by researchers working on scanning tunneling microscopy and scanning electrochemical microscopy. After nanomanufacturing of the probe tips, the PI and his team performed a series of proof-of-concept experiments to demonstrate the utility of the resulting products. Besides serving as sharp probes for near-field optical imaging and spectroscopy, these pyramidal tips can concurrently act as nanoscale “tweezers” to electronically capture nanoparticles or molecules.

The broader impacts of this project were the demonstration of wafer-scale nanomanufacturing and dissemination of high-quality metallic pyramidal tips. Detailed fabrication protocols have been published in peer-reviewed journal papers and presented at research conferences, which will help other researchers to duplicate the template-stripping fabrication process. The PI has also shared the resulting gold and silver pyramidal probes with researchers working at other universities for collaborative experiments.

A graduate student supported by this project has successfully defended his thesis and joined an industry research laboratory to apply his nanomanufacturing skills for applications in data storage industry. For K-12 educational outreach, the PI and his students visited the Science Museum of Minnesota and performed on-site scientific demos during annual NanoDays events. The PI has also mentored a local high school student for two years to guide his independent scientific project.


Last Modified: 10/16/2017
Modified by: Sang-Hyun Oh
